properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall totaling 30 to 60 mm continues this morning. The frozen ground will have a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Hazards: 30 to 60 mm of rainfall Timing: Rain will continue this morning before ending by noon Discussion: Steady rain this morning will ease to showers and then snow flurries this afternoon. A total of 30 to 60 mm of rain is expected across eastern Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T21:59:01-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few more hours of freezing rain possible this morning. Hazards: A few more hours of freezing rain Timing: Freezing rain possible at times early this morning before transitioning to a wintry mix Impacts: Local power outages may be possible due to ice build-up Poor road conditions due to ice accumulation Discussion: Freezing rain will change over to light snow this morning, with a risk of freezing drizzle. No significant snow accumulation is expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected today. Hazards: Locally 15 to 30 cm of snow today Quickly accumulating snow of 5+ cm per hour Blowing snow Poor visibility in heavy and blowing snow Timing: Now through this evening. Snow Squalls are also likely tonight and Saturday. Impacts: Hazardous to dangerous travel Discussion: Widespread snow continues this morning near Georgian Bay. Enhancement off Georgian Bay will help create heavier snow along the southern shore and higher terrain, with heavy snow and blowing snow at times. More pure lake effect will continue tonight and Saturday. Travel could be dangerous today and Saturday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-26T01:57:01-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain and windy conditions are expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h with higher wind gusts possible along the Fundy Coast and over higher terrain. Time span: Showers will develop today then become heavy rain this evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to switch to periods of snow Saturday afternoon before ending on Saturday evening. In addition, strong gusty winds will develop today and they will reach close to the warning criteria (90 km/h) along the Fundy Coast. These strong winds will diminish by Saturday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-26T04:55:51-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected today and tonight. Hazards: Locally 25 to 50 cm of snow in the heaviest bands, generally near Lake Huron Quickly accumulating snow at times Poor visibility in blowing snow and heavy falling snow Timing: Snow Squalls will be possible across the watch area today and tonight. Impacts: Hazardous driving conditions due to reduced visibilities and snow accumulation Discussion: Cold northwesterly winds flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Huron will generate snow squalls beginning Friday morning. Steady winds and sufficient temperatures will allow for blowing snow in areas with fresh snowfall. A general 5 to 10 cm can be expected with locally 25 to 50 cm in areas where bands settle for longer, generally near Lake Huron. Poor visibility will be a concern throughout the watch area. These snow squalls could potentially last into Saturday. However, winds will shift and the threat should likely remain closer to northern Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-26T03:23:17-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected today. Hazards: Locally 25 to 45 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow of 5+ cm per hour Blowing snow Poor visibility in heavy and blowing snow Timing: Now through this morning Impacts: Hazardous to dangerous travel Locations most impacted possibly include: London, Grand Bend, Parkhill, Strathroy, Lambton Shores, The Pinery Provincial Park, Melbourne, Mount Brydges, Komoka, Komoka Provincial Park and Ilderton. Discussion: Exeter weather RADAR shows a snow squall coming off Lake Huron at Grand Bend within a broader area of moderate snowfall. This snow squall should get more intense over the next several hours. A weather spotter in Parkhill has reported 16 cm of snow so far from system snow and now this band as of 4:30 a.m. Intense snowfall rates may be possible for several hours this morning before the band shifts north this afternoon. Blowing snow may accompany this snow squall as well. Travel could be dangerous. Note: heavy snow from the main low pressure system will continue in these areas as well over the next few hours. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T19:59:43-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, wet and windy conditions for today and Saturday followed by periods of snow late on Saturday. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, potentially locally higher amounts. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h with the highest gusts along the coast and over higher terrain, beginning today and diminishing on Saturday. Locations: northern and eastern New Brunswick. Time span: Light rain will begin today and intensify tonight and Saturday morning, before moving east of the province late on Saturday. Rain is expected to switch to snow for most areas on Saturday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today. Snow is expected to continue spreading north over Northeastern Ontario this morning. Snow will continue this afternoon and evening before ending overnight. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 15 cm are possible with this event with the highest amounts expected near the Quebec border. Although the snowfall amounts are not expected to meet the Snowfall Warning criteria of 15 cm or greater in 12 hours or less, there may be periods of heavy snow today that may make travel difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain over higher terrain coming to an end this morning. Places along the Ottawa River, such as Pembroke and Petawawa, are not expected to be impacted by freezing rain as much as higher terrain to the southwest. Hazards: Several hours of freezing rain, particularly over higher terrain Ice accretion of up to 5 mm Timing: Freezing rain will continue at times this morning before transitioning to scattered flurries with a risk of freezing drizzle this afternoon Impacts: Local power outages may be possible due to ice build-up ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls today and possibly this evening. A few isolated snow squalls may continue into Saturday north of London and along the Lake Huron shores. Hazards: Locally 25 to 45 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow of 5+ cm per hour Blowing snow Poor visibility in heavy and blowing snow Timing: Now through this morning and locally into the evening Impacts: Hazardous to dangerous travel Discussion: Exeter weather RADAR shows a few snow squalls coming off Lake Huron to all shorelines from just west of Grand Bend and northward with a broader area of moderate snowfall extending southeast of London. These snow squalls should get more intense today, however, they will become more isolated by this afternoon. Intense snowfall rates may be possible for several hours this morning before the band shifts north of Grand Bend this afternoon. Travel could be dangerous due to low visibilities. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Windy conditions for today and Saturday. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h with higher wind gusts possible over exposed areas. Location: all of Nova Scotia. Time span: today through Saturday evening. Remarks: In addition to gusty winds, which may cause power outages, scattered showers are also in store for today. Rain will develop tonight or Saturday for most for most of the province. Heavy rain is expected for southwestern Nova Scotia and parts of Cumberland County. As a result, rainfall warnings are in effect for those areas. Later on Saturday, rain is likely to switch to snow for some areas as the temperatures drops. Locally snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected, especially over higher terrain. Conditions will improve Saturday night. In addition, higher than normal water levels are expected from Lunenburg east to Sheet Harbour near 4 am AST on Saturday. Wave heights of up to 6 metres are expected along the Atlantic coast beginning early Saturday and persisting most of the day. Coastal flooding is not expected at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Several hours of freezing rain is possible this morning over higher terrain. Places along the Ottawa River, such as Pembroke and Petawawa, are not expected to be impacted by freezing rain as much as higher terrain areas to the southwest. Hazards: Several hours of freezing rain, particularly over higher terrain Ice accretion of up to 5 mm Timing: Freezing rain will continue at times this morning before transitioning to scattered flurries with a risk of freezing drizzle this afternoon Impacts: Local power outages may be possible due to ice build-up ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T19:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-25T13:51:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2627833658.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain and windy conditions are expected. Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h with higher wind gusts possible over exposed areas. Time span: Heavy rain is forecast to develop tonight or Saturday morning, and move east of the province Saturday evening or overnight. Remarks: rain is likely to switch to snow for some areas late Saturday afternoon or evening as the temperatures drop. Winds will strengthen, nearing warning levels for much of the province and there is potential for power outages to occur. Conditions will improve Saturday night. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-26T06:31:05-00:00
